items.title: Best finisher? Toughest opponent? - Shearer answers your questions
items.summary: Alan Shearer answers questions from the BBC Sport audience (and Dion Dublin) on Football Focus at Newcastle's St James' Park.

items.title: Appleâ€™s Services division is now bigger than Walt Disney or Tesla â€“ FT
items.summary: A new report says that Apple is expecting to announce annual Service revenues of well over $100 billion during its earnings report later this week. If accurate, that would make the companyâ€™s Services division a bigger business than either Walt Disney or Tesla â€¦ moreâ€¦

items.title: Apple's MacBook Air M4 is back on sale for $799
items.summary: Now's a great time to pick up a new MacBook Air if you've been thinking about taking the plunge. Amazon has the M4-powered, 13-inch MacBook Air for a record-low price of $799 right now. The 20 percent discount applies to multiple colors, too. We ranked this as our favorite Apple laptop in our list â€¦

items.title: Adobe's new Photoshop AI Assistant can automate repetitive tasks
items.summary: Among the usual slew of AI enhancements to its Creative Cloud apps, Adobe has introduced a new Photoshop AI Assistant to help automate repetitive chores and provide personalized recommendations. At Adobe Max 2025, the company also introduced new tools for Photoshop, Premiere and Lightroom, while laâ€¦

items.title: Adobe's Firefly can now use AI to generate soundtracks, speech and video
items.summary: Adobe has released the latest version of Firefly that now leans heavily on AI for nearly every facet of video and image post-production. The updated app can now use AI to generate narration, music, images and video clips, while even helping you to brainstorm ideas and piece together clips. Many creâ€¦

items.title: Insta360 X4 Air is a lightweight 8K 360-degree camera
items.summary: Insta360 has launched a new camera that sits between the X4 and its current flagship, the X5. The company says the new Insta360 X4 Air is lightest-ever 8K 360-degree camera at just 165 grams. It is definitely lighter than the 200-gram X5 and the 203-gram X4 cameras, but the company says it packs flâ€¦

items.title: YouTube Shorts will integrate Adobe Premiere's video editing tools
items.summary: Adobe Max kicked off today with a slew of announcements â€” mostly in the world of AI. But the company also used its creative conference to share that Adobe Premiere's video editing tools are being integrated into YouTube Shorts. It's no secret that YouTube has been taking every step it can to make Sâ€¦

items.title: Adobe launches AI assistants for Express and Photoshop
items.summary: Adobe today released new AI assistants Creative Cloud products, Express and Photoshop, that can help users with image creation and editing.

items.title: Lenovo Legion Go 2 review: The utility PC gaming handheld
items.summary: When the first big wave of handheld PCs hit the market two to three years ago, they were designed as more travel-friendly and convenient alternatives to traditional gaming rigs. That meant reduced performance in exchange for increased portability. However, there will always be enthusiasts who want â€¦

items.title: Grant to lead Australia with captain Yeo ruled out
items.summary: Australia will be in "great hands" with stand-in captain Harry Grant leading the side for the second Ashes Test against England, coach Kevin Walters says.

items.title: 'Climate change impacting marathon records'
items.summary: Rising temperatures have made record times in some races "nearly impossible", says new research.

items.title: US passport support in Apple Wallet is a hugely important step for digital ID
items.summary: We learned back at WWDC25 that US passport support would be coming to Apple Wallet. It hasnâ€™t yet arrived in iOS 26, but the company yesterday confirmed that it is on the way. An update to the Apple website last month told us to expect it by the end of the year, and Appleâ€™s VP of Apple Pay and Applâ€¦

items.title: Trumpâ€™s UCLA deal: Pay us $1B+, and we can still cut your grants again
items.summary: The deal wouldn't protect UCLA from the proposed university compact.
items.body: On Friday, the California Supreme Court ordered the University of California system to release the details of a proposed deal from the federal government that would restore research grants that were suspended by the Trump administration. The proposed deal, first issued in August, had remained confidential as a suit filed by faculty at UCLA made its way through appeals. With Californiaâ€™s top court now weighing in, the university administrators have released the document , still marked â€œdraftâ€ and â€œconfidential attorney work product.â€ Most of the demands will seem unsurprising to those familiar with the Trump administrationâ€™s interest: an end to all diversity programs and those supporting transgender individuals, plus a sharp crackdown on campus protests. The eye-opening portion comes at the price tag of nearly $1.2 billion paid out, with UCLA covering all the costs of compliance. And, as written, the deal wouldnâ€™t stop the Trump administration from cutting the grants for other reasons or imposing more intrusive regulations, such as those mentioned in its university compact . Familiar concerns In many ways, the proposed deal is much more focused than the odd list of demands the admiâ€¦

items.title: In Pictures: Sporting photos of the week
items.summary: A selection of some of the most striking sports photographs taken around the world over the past seven days.

items.title: Trump and Republicans join Big Oilâ€™s push to shut down climate liability efforts
items.summary: Republicans are attempting to foreclose the ability of cities and states to seek damages linked to climate change.
items.body: As efforts continue to hold some of the worldâ€™s largest fossil fuel corporations liable for destructive and deadly climate impacts, backlash from the politically powerful oil and gas industry and its allies in government is on the rise, bolstered by the Trump administrationâ€™s allegiance to fossil fuels. From lobbying Congress for liability protection to suing states over their climate liability laws and lawsuits, attempts to shield Big Oil from potential liability and to shut down climate accountability initiatives are advancing on multiple fronts. â€œThe effort has escalated dramatically in the past six or seven months,â€ said Richard Wiles, president of the Center for Climate Integrity, an organization that advocates for holding fossil fuel companies accountable for selling products they knew were dangerously warming the planet. Read full article Comments

items.title: The Morning After: Rivian spinoff Also made a modular e-bike with a virtual drivetrain
items.summary: Spinning off from Rivian, the TM-B e-bike is Alsoâ€™s attempt at a do-it-all e-bike. Itâ€™s pitching it as flexible enough for commuting, trail riding or kid- and cargo-hauling because its modular frame can swap in bench seats or cargo racks. But the frame only comes in a single size. Still, Also (hateâ€¦

items.title: Porscheâ€™s 2026 911 Turbo S is a ballistic, twin-turbo, 701-horsepower monster
items.summary: Big power, no lag, surprising agility make for a stellar driveâ€”at an astronomical cost.
items.body: Porsche provided flights from Albany, New York, to Malaga, Spain, and accommodation so Ars could drive the 911 Turbo S. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. Turbochargers have been injecting more power into engines for over 100 years, but never before have they been so prevalent in our cars. A little boost can add a lot of power and efficiency, too, making a turbocharger a great solution to eke maximum performance out of todayâ€™s engines. Usually, though, that comes with the penalty of throttle lag: You put your foot to the floor, and nothing much happens for a beat or two. As weâ€™ve recently seen in our review of the new 911 GTS , Porscheâ€™s engineers have worked some magic to create a turbocharger that provides all the power and fun of forced induction but with none of the throttle response penalty. If adding one high-tech, high-voltage turbocharger is good, surely two would be better, right? Indeed, it is, if you can afford the cost of entry. Meet the 701 hp (523 kW) 2026 911 Turbo S, Porscheâ€™s new most powerful 911 ever. Twinning the T-Hybrid For Porscheâ€™s first hybrid 911, the GTS, the company didnâ€™t simply add an electric motor and bigger battery into the mix and call itâ€¦

items.title: AI-powered search engines rely on â€œless popularâ€ sources, researchers find
items.summary: Generative search engines often cite sites that wouldn't appear in Google's top 100 links.
items.body: Since last yearâ€™s disastrous rollout of Googleâ€™s AI Overviews , the world at large has been aware of how AI-powered search results can differ wildly from the traditional list of links search engines have generated for decades. Now, new research helps quantify that difference, showing that AI search engines tend to cite less popular websites and ones that wouldnâ€™t even appear in the Top 100 links listed in an â€œorganicâ€ Google search. In the pre-print paper â€œ Characterizing Web Search in The Age of Generative AI ,â€ researchers from Ruhr University in Bochum, Germany, and the Max Planck Institute for Software Systems compared traditional link results from Googleâ€™s search engine to its AI Overviews and Gemini-2.5-Flash . The researchers also looked at GPT-4oâ€™s web search mode and the separate â€œGPT-4o with Search Tool,â€ which resorts to searching the web only when the LLM decides it needs information found outside its own pre-trained data. The researchers drew test queries from a number of sources, including specific questions submitted to ChatGPT in the WildChat dataset , general political topics listed on AllSides , and products included in the 100 most-searched Amazon products list.â€¦

items.title: AT&T ad congratulating itself for its ethics violated an ad-industry rule
items.summary: Ad industry watchdog says AT&T violated program rule, demands removal of ads.
items.body: AT&T committed a big no-no in its latest advertising campaign against T-Mobile, according to the organization that runs the ad industryâ€™s self-regulatory system. BBB National Programsâ€™ National Advertising Division said Friday that AT&T â€œviolated Section 2.1(I) of the National Advertising Division (NAD)/National Advertising Review Board (NARB) Procedures for the US advertising industryâ€™s process of self-regulation by issuing a video advertisement and press release that use the NAD process and its findings for promotional purposes. NAD has demanded that AT&T immediately remove such violative promotional materials and cease all future dissemination.â€ The NAD said that AT&Tâ€™s action threatens the â€œintegrity and success of the self-regulatory forum,â€ and â€œundermines NADâ€™s mission to promote truth and accuracy of advertising claims and foster consumer trust in the marketplace.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: 25 years, one website: ISS in Real Time captures quarter-century on space station
items.summary: From the makers of Apollo in Real Time comes a site with 500 times more data.
items.body: With the milestone just days away, you are likely to hear this week that there has now been a continuous human presence on the International Space Station (ISS) for the past 25 years. But what does that quarter of a century actually encompass? If only there was a way to see, hear, and experience each of those 9,131 days . Fortunately, the astronauts and cosmonauts on the space station have devoted some of their work time and a lot of their free time to taking photos, filming videos, and calling down to Earth. Much of that data has been made available to the public, but in separate repositories, with no real way to correlate or connect it with the timeline on which it was all created. Read full article Comments

items.title: F1 in Mexico City: We have a new championship leader
items.summary: It was a quiet race for the win, but there was plenty of action for second and third.
items.body: Mexico City is one of the more unusual places that Formula 1 races, and itâ€™s all thanks to altitude. The city sits at than 7,350 feet (2,240 m) above sea level, which makes the air noticeably thin compared to the average Grand Prix held at sea level. Like humans, F1 cars need air. Oxygen is necessary if you want any internal combustion to happen inside the turbocharged 1.6 L V6 engine. A good flow of air across the various radiators and heat exchangers in the car is vital if you want to make it to the end of the race. And the downforce-generating wings and underbody only generate downforce by creating differences in air pressure above and below the car. At over a mile above sea level, thereâ€™s about 20 percent less air, and therefore less power created by combustion, less efficient cooling of the cars, and less downforce able to be generated. items.title: Why imperfection could be key to Turing patterns in nature
items.summary: Many Turing mechanism models yield too-perfect patterns; varying cell sizes vastly improves the results.
items.body: A mixture of two types of pigment-producing cells undergoes diffusiophoretic transport to self-assemble into a hexagonal pattern. Credit: Siamak Mirfendereski and Ankur Gupta/CU Boulder A mixture of two types of pigment-producing cells undergoes diffusiophoretic transport to self-assemble into a hexagonal pattern. Credit: Siamak Mirfendereski and Ankur Gupta/CU Boulder A zebraâ€™s distinctive black-and-white stripes, or a leopardâ€™s spots, are both examples of â€œ Turing patterns ,â€ after mathematician and computer scientist Alan Turing, who proposed an intriguing hypothetical mechanism for how such complex, irregular patterns might emerge in nature. But Turingâ€™s original proposal proved too simplified to fully re-create those natural patterns. Scientists at the University of Colorado at Boulder (UCB) have devised a new modeling approach that achieves much more accurate final patterns by introducing deliberate imperfections, according to a new paper published in the journal Matter. Turing focused on chemicals known as morphogens in his seminal 1952 paper . He devised a mechanism involving the interaction between an activator chemical that expresses a unique characteristic (like a tigerâ€¦

items.body: Hurricane Melissa will make landfall in southern Jamaica less than 24 hours from now, and it is likely to be the most catastrophic storm in the Caribbean islandâ€™s history. As it crawled across the northern Caribbean Sea on Monday morning, Melissa officially became a Category 5 hurricane with 160 mph winds, according to the National Hurricane Center. The hurricane will likely fluctuate in intensity over the next day or so, perhaps undergoing an eyewall replacement cycle. But the background conditions, including very warm Caribbean waters and low wind shear, will support a very powerful hurricane and the potential for further strengthening. Read full article Comments

items.title: New image-generating AIs are being used for fake expense reports
items.summary: Software provider AppZen said fake AI receipts accounted for about 14% of fraud attempts.
items.body: Businesses are increasingly being deceived by employees using artificial intelligence for an age-old scam: faking expense receipts. The launch of new image-generation models by top AI groups such as OpenAI and Google in recent months has sparked an influx of AI-generated receipts submitted internally within companies, according to leading expense software platforms. Software provider AppZen said fake AI receipts accounted for about 14 percent of fraudulent documents submitted in September, compared with none last year. Fintech group Ramp said its new software flagged more than $1 million in fraudulent invoices within 90 days. Read full article Comments

items.title: 10M people watched a YouTuber shim a lock; the lock company sued him. Bad idea.
items.summary: It's still legal to pick locks, even when you swing your legs.
items.body: â€œOpening locksâ€ might not sound like scintillating social media content, but Trevor McNally has turned lock-busting into online gold. A former US Marine Staff Sergeant, McNally today has more than 7 million followers and has amassed more than 2 billion views just by showing how easy it is to open many common locks by slapping, picking, or shimming them. This does not always endear him to the companies that make the locks. On March 3, 2025, a Florida lock company called Proven Industries released a social media promo video just begging for the McNally treatment. The video was called, somewhat improbably, â€œYOU GUYS KEEP SAYING YOU CAN EASILY BREAK OFF OUR LATCH PIN LOCK.â€ In it, an enthusiastic man in a ball cap says he will â€œprove a lot of you haters wrong.â€ He then goes hard at Provenâ€™s $130 model 651 trailer hitch lock with a sledgehammer, bolt cutters, and a crowbar. Read full article Comments

items.title: Whale and dolphin migrations are being disrupted by climate change
items.summary: Marine mammals are being forced into new and more dangerous waters, scientists warn.
items.body: For millennia, some of the worldâ€™s largest filter-feeding whales, including humpbacks, fin whales, and blue whales, have undertaken some of the longest migrations on earth to travel between their warm breeding grounds in the tropics to nutrient-rich feeding destinations in the poles each year. â€œNature has finely tuned these journeys, guided by memory and environmental cues that tell whales when to move and where to go,â€ said Trisha Atwood, an ecologist and associate professor at Utah State Universityâ€™s Quinney College of Agriculture and Natural Resources. But, she said, climate change is â€œscrambling these signals,â€ forcing the marine mammals to veer off course. And theyâ€™re not alone. Earlier this year, Atwood joined more than 70 other scientists to discuss the global impacts of climate change on migratory species in a workshop convened by the United Nations Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals. The organization monitors and protects more than 1,000 species that cross borders in search of food, mates, and favorable conditions to nurture their offspring. Read full article Comments

items.title: Are you the asshole? Of course not!â€”quantifying LLMsâ€™ sycophancy problem
items.summary: In new research, AI models show a troubling tendency to agree with whatever the user says.
items.body: Researchers and users of LLMs have long been aware that AI models have a troubling tendency to tell people what they want to hear , even if that means being less accurate. But many reports of this phenomenon amount to mere anecdotes that donâ€™t provide much visibility into how common this sycophantic behavior is across frontier LLMs. Two recent research papers have come at this problem a bit more rigorously, though, taking different tacks in attempting to quantify exactly how likely an LLM is to listen when a user provides factually incorrect or socially inappropriate information in a prompt. Solve this flawed theorem for me In one pre-print study published this month, researchers from Sofia University and ETH Zurich looked at how LLMs respond when false statements are presented as the basis for difficult mathematical proofs and problems. The BrokenMath benchmark that the researchers constructed starts with â€œa diverse set of challenging theorems from advanced mathematics competitions held in 2025.â€ Those problems are then â€œperturbedâ€ into versions that are â€œdemonstrably false but plausibleâ€ by an LLM thatâ€™s checked with expert review. Read full article Comments

items.title: A single point of failure triggered the Amazon outage affecting millions
items.summary: A DNS manager in a single region of Amazon's sprawling network touched off a 16-hour debacle.
items.body: The outage that hit Amazon Web Services and took out vital services worldwide was the result of a single failure that cascaded from system to system within Amazonâ€™s sprawling network, according to a post-mortem from company engineers. The series of failures lasted for 15 hours and 32 minutes, Amazon said . Network intelligence company Ookla said its DownDetector service received more than 17 million reports of disrupted services offered by 3,500 organizations. The three biggest countries where reports originated were the US, the UK, and Germany. Snapchat, AWS, and Roblox were the most reported services affected. Ookla said the event was â€œamong the largest internet outages on record for Downdetector.â€ Itâ€™s always DNS Amazon said the root cause of the outage was a software bug in software running the DynamoDB DNS management system. The system monitors the stability of load balancers by, among other things, periodically creating new DNS configurations for endpoints within the AWS network. A race condition is an error that makes a process dependent on the timing or sequence events that are variable and outside the developersâ€™ control. The result can be unexpected behavior and potentiaâ€¦

items.title: Man takes herbal pain quackery, nearly dies, spends months in hospital
items.summary: The 61-year-old had wounds all over, a bacterial infection, and needed intensive care.
items.body: A 61-year-old man in California is lucky to be alive after a combination of herbal supplements he was taking for joint pain ended up utterly wrecking his body, landing him in intensive care and in a delirious state for months. His case is reported in the Annals of Internal Medicine: Clinical Cases . The man turned up at a hospital in San Francisco in bad shape, but with nonspecific problems that had begun just two days earlier. His back hurt, he was feverish, nauseous, bloated, and he hadnâ€™t been eating much. He was so weak he couldnâ€™t walk or get out of bed without help. His heart rate and breathing rate were high. His blood pressure was low. There were multiple wounds on his lower body in various stages of healing. Initial exams and lab work revealed Staphylococcus aureus bacteria in his blood. There was also an abscess on his shoulder and an infection in and around his spine, which was worsening. Doctors wanted to perform a surgical procedure to relieve the pressure building up on his spinal cord and nerves, but his blood pressure was too lowâ€”and then he went into hemorrhagic shock from bleeding in his gastrointestinal tract. Doctors transferred him to the intensive care unit. â€¦

items.title: Clinical trial of a technique that could give everyone the best antibodies
items.summary: If we ID the DNA for a great antibody, anyone can now make it.
items.body: One of the things that emerging diseases, including the COVID and Zika pandemics, have taught us is that itâ€™s tough to keep up with infectious diseases in the modern world. Things like air travel can allow a virus to spread faster than our ability to develop therapies. But that doesnâ€™t mean biotech has stood still; companies have been developing technologies that could allow us to rapidly respond to future threats. There are a lot of ideas out there. But this week saw some early clinical trial results of one technique that could be useful for a range of infectious diseases. Weâ€™ll go over the results as a way to illustrate the sort of thinking thatâ€™s going on, along with the technologies we have available to pursue the resulting ideas. The best antibodies Any emerging disease leaves a mass of antibodies in its wakeâ€”those made by people in response to infections and vaccines, those made by lab animals we use to study the infectious agent, and so on. Some of these only have a weak affinity for the disease-causing agent, but some of them turn out to be what are called â€œbroadly neutralizing.â€ These stick with high affinity not only to the original pathogen, but most or all of its variaâ€¦

items.title: The Android-powered Boox Palma 2 Pro fits in your pocket, but itâ€™s not a phone
items.summary: This e-reader has a color screen and 5G.
items.body: Digital reading devices like the Kindle have existed for almost 20 years, and the standard eReader form factor has hardly changed at all. Amazon, Boox, and a few other companies have offered larger E Ink screens, but how about something smaller? Boox has unveiled its second-generation Palma e-reader, which still fits in your pocket but adds a color screen and mobile data connectivity. The first-gen Palma launched last year, earning fans who saw it as a way to read and access some apps without the full spate of distracting smartphone experiences. Boox e-readers are essentially Android tablets with E Ink screens and a few software quirks that arise from their unofficial Google Play implementation. The second-gen Palma might offer more opportunities for distraction because itâ€™s almost a smartphone. The Palma 2 Pro upgrades the 6.1-inch monochrome display from the original to a 6.13-inch color E Ink Kaleido display. Thatâ€™s the same technology used in Amazonâ€™s Kindle Colorsoft . The Amazon reader is a bit larger with its 7-inch display and chunkier bezels. Of course, the Kindle isnâ€™t trying to fit in your pocket like the Palma 2 Pro, which is roughly the size and shape of a phone. Readâ€¦

items.title: Teslaâ€™s â€œMad Maxâ€ mode is now under federal scrutiny
items.summary: The new mode added in the latest update will speed and weave through traffic.
items.body: Earlier this month, Tesla rolled out a new firmware update that added a pair of new driving modes for the controversial full self-driving (FSD) feature. One, called â€œSloth,â€ relaxes acceleration and stays in its lane. The other, called â€œMad Max,â€ does the opposite: It speeds and swerves through traffic to get you to your destination faster. And after multiple reports of FSD Teslas doing just that, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration wants to know more. In fact, â€œMad Maxâ€ mode is not entirely newâ€”Tesla beta-tested the same feature in Autopilot in 2018, before deciding not to roll it out in a production release after widespread outcry. These days, the company is evidently feeling less constrained; despite having just lost a federal wrongful death lawsuit that will cost it hundreds of millions of dollars , it described the new mode as being able to drive â€œthrough traffic at an incredible pace, all while still being super smooth. It drives your car like a sports car. If you are running late, this is the mode for you.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: EU accuses Meta of violating content rules in move that could anger Trump
items.summary: EU alleges Facebook and Instagram make it too hard to report illegal content.
items.body: Meta violated the Digital Services Act (DSA) by failing to give Facebook and Instagram users simple mechanisms to report illegal content, the European Commission said in a preliminary decision announced yesterday. Meta also failed to give users an effective way to challenge content moderation decisions, the EC said. â€œWhen it comes to Meta, neither Facebook nor Instagram appear to provide a user-friendly and easily accessible â€˜Notice and Actionâ€™ mechanism for users to flag illegal content, such as child sexual abuse material and terrorist content,â€ the EC press release said. The EC said that Meta mechanisms seem to â€œimpose several unnecessary steps and additional demands on users. In addition, both Facebook and Instagram appear to use so-called â€˜dark patterns,â€™ or deceptive interface designs, when it comes to the â€˜Notice and Actionâ€™ mechanisms.â€ The EC also found that the content moderation appeal mechanisms used by Facebook and Instagram do not â€œallow users to provide explanations or supporting evidence to substantiate their appeals. This makes it difficult for users in the EU to further explain why they disagree with Metaâ€™s content decision, limiting the effectiveness of the appeâ€¦

items.title: Why the next generation of mRNA vaccines is set to be even better
items.summary: mRNA vaccines are quick and easy to make, while virus-like nanoparticles produce a stronger immune response. Now, the two approaches are being combined to give us the best of both worlds

items.title: Ancient lead exposure may have influenced how our brains evolved
items.summary: Lead poisoning isn't just a modern phenomenon: fossil teeth show signs that it affected ancient hominids, and Homo sapiens may have coped better than our close relatives

items.title: We've hit a climate tipping point, but leaders seem unlikely to act
items.summary: A report on the state of the climate has concluded coral reefs are on a knife-edge, even as the world shifts away from making good on net zero

items.title: Can chilli powder really stop animals from digging up your garden?
items.summary: Chilli powder is touted as a cheap, easy, safe option to protect your garden from foxes and squirrels. James Wong casts a scientific eye on this popular remedy

items.title: If you love AI, you'll love Ken Liu's new cyberpunk thriller
items.summary: In Ken Liu's All That We See or Seem, a once-famous hacker must find a missing dream-weaver. One for AI fans, but it didn't quite work for Emily H. Wilson

items.title: A purrfect guide to cats and our complex relationship with them
items.summary: Our bond with cats â€“ which has seen them go from hunter to house pet â€“ may be more diverse than with any other animal. And Jerry D. Moore's Cat Tales: A history rounds up the lot, says Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Is it really likely that humans will go extinct in exactly 314 years?
items.summary: Feedback isn't entirely convinced by a new piece of research that claims by 2339 "there will be no humans", even though the authors used three methods to make their calculation

items.title: There is a major psychological flaw in how society punishes people
items.summary: Our experiments have revealed that we're getting it wrong when it comes to crime and punishment. This is undermining society, say Raihan Alam and Tage Rai

items.title: New Scientist recommends Sheri S. Tepper's science fiction novel Grass
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: Del Toro's Frankenstein is a sumptuous take on a classic parable
items.summary: With enthralling visuals and intense performances, this version of Mary Shelley's sci-fi tale reminds us to ask not only if we can create life, but if we can live with our creations, says Davide Abbatescianni

items.title: Dinosaur fossil rewrites the story of how sauropods got long necks
items.summary: A 230-million-year-old fossil found in Argentina shows that the evolution of sauropod dinosaursâ€™ long necks began earlier than previously thought

items.title: The 30-year fight over how many numbers we need to describe reality
items.summary: In 1992, three physicists began an argument about how many numbers we need to fully describe the universe. Their surprisingly long-running quarrel takes us to the heart of whatâ€™s truly real

items.title: CO2 levels in Earth's atmosphere jumped by a record amount in 2024
items.summary: The global average concentration of CO2 surged by 3.5 parts per million to reach 423.9 ppm last year, fuelling worries that the planetâ€™s ability to soak up excess carbon is weakening

items.title: The AI bubble is heading towards a burst but it won't be the end of AI
items.summary: Economists, bankers and even the boss of OpenAI are warning of a rapidly inflating AI bubble. If and when it bursts, what will happen to the technological breakthroughs of the past few years?

items.title: Who were the first humans to reach the British Isles?
items.summary: As ancient humans left Africa, they encountered many harsh environments including the Sahara and the high Arctic, but one of the last places they inhabited was Britain, likely due to the relentless cold and damp climate

items.title: Paralysed man can feel objects through another person's hand
items.summary: Keith Thomas, a man in his 40s with no sensation or movement in his hands, is able to feel and move objects by controlling another person's hand via a brain implant. The technique might one day even allow us to experience another person's body over long distances.

items.title: Martian volcanoes may have transported ice to the planet's equator
items.summary: The equatorial regions of Mars are home to unexpectedly enormous layers of ice, and they may have been put there by dramatic volcanic eruptions billions of years ago

items.title: Weâ€™re finally reading the secrets of Herculaneumâ€™s lost library
items.summary: A whole libraryâ€™s worth of papyri owned by Julius Caesarâ€™s father-in-law were turned to charcoal by the eruption of Vesuvius. Nearly 2000 years later, we can at last read these lost treasures

items.title: 'Pregnancy test' for skeletons could help reveal ancient mothers
items.summary: Progesterone, oestrogen and testosterone can be detected in skeletons over 1000 years old, offering a way to identify individuals who died while pregnant or soon after giving birth

items.title: Mother's voice seems to boost language development in premature babies
items.summary: Babies born too soon seem to have stronger connections in one of the major brain areas that supports language processing if they regularly heard their mother read them a story while in intensive care

items.title: A radical rethink of what makes your diet healthy or bad for you
items.summary: What you eat has a surprising impact on the pH of your body with wide ranging impacts on your health. But getting the balance right isnâ€™t as simple as eating fewer acidic foods

items.title: Chatbots work best when you speak to them with formal language
items.summary: Are you terse and informal when speaking to an AI chatbot? If so, you might be getting worse answers than if you used more formal language

items.title: What makes a quantum computer good?
items.summary: Claims that one quantum computer is better than another rest on terms like quantum advantage or quantum supremacy, fault-tolerance or qubits with better coherence â€“ what does it all mean? Karmela Padavic-Callaghan sifts through the noise

items.title: Coral reefs are at a tipping point after surging global temperatures
items.summary: Record-breaking ocean temperatures have caused widespread bleaching and death among warm-water corals, which could have far-reaching consequences

items.title: Physicists are uncovering when natureâ€™s strongest force falters
items.summary: The strong nuclear force may abruptly loosen its grip on the fundamental particles that make up matter at a special â€œcritical pointâ€ â€“ researchers are now getting a clearer picture of when that point is reached

items.title: Serum based on plant extracts boosts hair growth in weeks
items.summary: Applying a daily serum that contains extracts of a tropical plant improved hair density and strand thickness in just 56 days

items.title: Evolution of intelligence in our ancestors may have come at a cost
items.summary: By tracing when variations in the human genome first appeared, researchers have found that advances in cognitive abilities may have led to our vulnerability to mental illness

items.title: 'Sword Dragon' ichthyosaur had enormous eyes and a lethal snout
items.summary: A beautifully preserved skeleton found on the UKâ€™s Jurassic Coast has been identified as a new species of the marine reptiles known as ichthyosaurs

items.title: Robotic underwater glider sets out to circumnavigate the globe
items.summary: Redwing, a robotic submarine about the size of a surfboard, is embarking on a five-year journey that will follow the famed explorer Ferdinand Magellanâ€™s voyage around the world

items.title: Therapy may be the most effective way to ease irritable bowel syndrome
items.summary: People with irritable bowel syndrome are often only given treatments like cognitive behavioural therapy after others have failed, but research suggests this approach is more effective than we thought

items.title: We've discovered another reason why naked mole rats live for so long
items.summary: The longevity of naked mole rats may partly be due to them having a variant of a key protein that boosts DNA repair â€“ a discovery that could help extend our own lives

items.title: Swirly lasers can control an ungovernable cousin of magnetism
items.summary: Short pulses of light that impart rotation on a material's atoms can be used to switch a property called ferroaxiality, which could let us build very stable and efficient memory devices

items.title: Hidden ecosystem of the ovaries plays a surprising role in fertility
items.summary: A woman's fertility declines with age, which is often attributed to a fall in egg number and quality, but the environment of the ovaries themselves may also be responsible

items.title: Top 250 oil and gas firms own just 1.5% of the world's renewable power
items.summary: Despite public promises by many fossil fuel firms that they are investing in the green transition, it turns out that they have made little contribution to the growth of renewable energy

items.title: King Richard III's oral microbiome hints he had severe gum disease
items.summary: The skeleton of King Richard III, which was found beneath a car park more than a decade ago, has well-preserved teeth, allowing scientists to sequence his oral microbiome

items.title: Pig liver transplant into a living person edges it closer to the norm
items.summary: The first ever transplantation of a pig's liver into a living person helps us better understand how animal organs can be used to prolong, or even save, lives

items.title: Electrons inside graphene have been pushed to supersonic speeds
items.summary: Making electrons flow like a liquid is difficult, but inside graphene researchers forced them to move so fast that they created dramatic shockwaves

items.title: Stunning images highlight fight to save Earthâ€™s rich biodiversity
items.summary: From an alien-looking flat-faced longhorn beetle to an abandoned baby rhino, images at Londonâ€™s Natural History Museum show what we stand to lose from the decimation of global biodiversity

items.title: Learning to play nice with other people
items.summary: How did cooperation emerge in a cut-throat world? There are clues in the prisoner's dilemma experiment, says Peter Rowlett

items.title: Blue Planet Red is wrong about Mars â€“ but it's surprisingly poignant
items.summary: Brian Cory Dobbs's documentary promotes the baseless idea that Mars was once inhabited by an advanced civilisation. But there's some value in how it inadvertently documents a generation of otherwise-sensible scientists, says Simon Ings

items.title: Hannah Ritchie's new book on net zero is a breath of fresh air
items.summary: Clearing the Air answers all your burning questions about the net-zero transition, with optimistic, data-led insights designed to address misinformation about climate change, says Madeleine Cuff

items.title: We are horrified to discover that not every rose has a thorn
items.summary: Feedback is shocked to learn that one of our most cherished metaphors involving roses and thorns really needs to be revisited. That's what happens when you invite the botanists to play

items.title: Why not all ultra-processed foods are bad for you
items.summary: Just because a food is ultra-processed doesnâ€™t mean it is unhealthy. Regulation and eating advice must reflect this, say Julia Belluz and Kevin Hall, co-authors of Food Intelligence: The science of how food both nourishes and harms us

items.title: The Whispers of Rock is a personal journey through aeons of geology
items.summary: In her new book, earth scientist Anjana Khatwa writes a love letter to Earth's rocks and mountains, offering a passionate blend of science and spirituality
